body:
Termdebug only works for gdb, which is a major disappointment for the users who've wanted an integrated debugger for years, but don't compile in gcc (or perhaps not at all).

[Vimspector](https://github.com/puremourning/vimspector) implements the [Debug Adapter Protocol](https://microsoft.github.io/debug-adapter-protocol/) (DAP) for Vim, which is a common interface to interop with a lot of different debuggers. The author is working to integrate it with Neovim, but is running into some issues concerning our API; see the [discussion](https://github.com/puremourning/vimspector/issues/29) and his [current progress](https://github.com/puremourning/vimspector/pull/77).

Given that we've already merged a debugger plugin from Vim and that we already like to work with protocols like LSP (DAP is the LSP of debuggers, you could say), would you consider an upgrade of termdebug to implement DAP and interface with a multitude of debuggers?

comment_data.body: This would be a welcome contribution. But there is no requirement that it be based on termdebug, likely it is better to develop a DAP client in Lua from scratch (and borrow pieces from termdebug if they be useful).

> But there is no requirement that it be based on termdebug

Then, for sake of cohesiveness, we should plan to deprecate our support for termdebug. That way, there isn't one Vim-compatible interface for gdb and one non-Vim-compatible interface for everything else.

Edit: This is, of course, when the planned DAP implementation is stable.

@bfredl I'm ready to get a PR going if you don't have any other questions or objections. My plan is to write and test the core functionality in Lua, but bind it to the Neovim interface with VimL. I'd also appreciate your continued support in code review on this!

Edit: Forgot to mention that I was planning to start with a fork of Vimspector, as given above, and then port the Python parts to Lua. Then, we could rethink the interface if necessary (I don't think it should be), and start writing configurations for different debuggers.

> Then, for sake of cohesiveness, we should plan to deprecate our support for termdebug

Maybe. No rush, but if we end up with something like `vim.lsp` then we can kiss TermDebug goodbye.

> Forgot to mention that I was planning to start with a fork of Vimspector, as given above, and then port the Python parts to Lua

That might be a useful experiment, but it might be "too much". I would start small (TermDebug might be a better starting point). See what core pieces are missing. E.g. I can imagine that  a popup abstraction will be helpful. 

NB: don't create dozens of new files scattered everywhere. Keep everything in one file, `runtime/lua/vim/dap.lua` .

> Then, for sake of cohesiveness, we should plan to deprecate our support for termdebug

Termdebug is just some vimL code in a single file, nothing needs to be planned to deprecate it. Deprecating it would just mean that we have some other option that we recommend before it.

> That might be a useful experiment, but it might be "too much". I would start small (TermDebug might be a better starting point). See what core pieces are missing. E.g. I can imagine that a popup abstraction will be helpful.

But vimspector is an implementation of DAP in the first place, while TermDebug is not, that the later is "smaller" is irrelevant. Having parts of the implementation be inspired by vimspector sounds perfectly fine (but we can revise design choices that don't make sense to us). For interface things like popups, signs, highlights etc,  try to reuse stuff in `vim/lsp/util.lua` where it makes sense (or even add stuff to it. don't worry that it is under lsp umbrella, we can move the file later)

> But vimspector is an implementation of DAP in the first place, while TermDebug is not, that the later is "smaller" and irrelevant

My concerns exactly. I've had the chance to play around with TermDebug earlier today, and it's essentially just a `:terminal` that runs gdb along with a command to open a buffer and highlight the current line on `:Next`. There's a lot more work that we could get for free from Vimspector in terms of UI and interface.

The main problem I see with Vimspector is that its core is in Python, not Lua.

> Then, we can focus on porting the core; it can be a line-by-line, function-by-function, port, as long as it supports the same protocol and eventually holds up to a more rigorous testing strategy.

Transliteration is the part that seems potentially like busy work to me. I'm only speculating though, I haven't looked at it. Certainly it may be helpful to take its DAP routines.

I think "transliteration with an open eye" is fine. I e start with the vimspector implementation, but reuse existing LSP abstractions as possible or even improve/generalize them (relevant for both json-rpc and interface stuff). and yes focus on the "core" protocol first  (and expose it for plugins/configs to hook into, like we did for LSP), rather than all the specific behavioral choices of vimspector.

> I think "transliteration with an open eye" is fine

Maybe I shouldn't have stressed rigorous transliteration too much. It just has to be API-compatible; we can use existing LSP abstractions where possible, for sure.

We'll have to have a rigorous rearchitecture discussion in each step, but it's better in the long-term. To my understanding, there's no rush for this feature either.
Sure. I think you can just go ahead and code something, we discuss more when you have a PR (or some specific question)

>  I was planning to start with a fork of Vimspector

sigh.

@puremourning we didn't know neovim support in vimspector was this close to get done when dicussing this earlier today. If vimspector now has full support, this obviously becomes less prioritized for neovim as a whole.

Still, if a contributor like @hariamoor wants to extend our json-rpc/LSP abstractions to implement DAP this is a welcome effort. Language choices like "forking" and "transliteration" might have been unfortunate but is natural that such a project will be inspired by an other implementation of the same protocol.
Vimspector neovim support just landed in master.
yes, that was I meant with "this close".
See PR #11739 here. I've added Vimspector as a [Git subtree](https://manpages.debian.org/testing/git-man/git-subtree.1.en.html) into `runtime/pack`, same place as TermDebug. Stay tuned, guys!
What does this mean, NeoVim to come packaged with an additional big python plugin ripped off someone's work? If that's the case, it doesn't look good at all.

@oblitum Neovim comes packed with _what_? A contributor has opened a draft PR, which means it is not meant to be merged in the present shape. Either they follow though with their plan and we get something concrete to at least discuss, or they do nothing and we just close the PR.
@oblitum That, and the version we ship would be written in Lua and have a number of differences.

I started with a [plugin from scratch](https://github.com/mfussenegger/nvim-dap) that works (or intends to, not much there yet) in a similar way as the LSP support in neovim does.

Not sure if it will get anywhere but could be another option for integration if it does get somewhere and if there is interest.

milestone.description: Low priority items. We plan to work on this but don't have a target date.
milestone.title: backlog

title: Debug Adapter Protocol implementation

type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality
type.name: Enhancement
